title: 14-D
statement: D. Two Pathstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test64 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutAs you know, Bob's brother lives in Flatland. In Flatland there arencities, connected byn- 1two-way roads. The cities are numbered from 1 ton. You can get from one city to another moving along the roads.The «Two Paths» company, where Bob's brother works, has won a tender to repair two paths in Flatland. A path is a sequence of different cities, connected sequentially by roads. The company is allowed to choose by itself the paths to repair. The only condition they have to meet is that the two paths shouldn't cross (i.e. shouldn't have common cities).It is known that the profit, the «Two Paths» company will get, equals the product of the lengths of the two paths. Let's consider the length of each road equals 1, and the length of a path equals the amount of roads in it. Find the maximum possible profit for the company.InputThe first line contains an integern(2 ≤n≤ 200), wherenis the amount of cities in the country. The followingn- 1lines contain the information about the roads. Each line contains a pair of numbers of the cities, connected by the roadai,bi(1 ≤ai,bi≤n).OutputOutput the maximum possible profit.ExamplesInput41 22 33 4Output1Input71 21 31 41 51 61 7Output0Input61 22 32 45 46 4Output4
